table.name: mem
table.column: This refers to the sound, and not to any letter or glyph.
Namnet på ett ljud, inte en skriven bokstav eller glyf.

table.name: mem
table.column: This word is also used when Klingons talk about an account that one signs up for to use a service, such as a computer accounts. See {mab:n:2}.

This is defined only as "treaty" in {TKD:src}. The additional definitions come from {Saarbrücken qepHom'a' 2016:src}.
Possibly a reference to the fairy Queen Mab in Romeo and Juliet, who is known for making bargains with mortals.

table.name: mem
table.column: This is an extension of {mab:n:1} to mean an account that someone can sign up for to use a service, such as a computer account. The verb to sign up for an account is {qI':v:2}. To log in to an account is {ngaQHa'moH:v:2}, and to log off is {ngaQmoH:v:2}.
This was used in Netflix's Klingon language promotional material.

table.name: mem
table.column: жабоподобное или похожее на лягушку существо [AUTOTRANSLATED]
eräs rupikonnaa tai sammakkoa muistuttava eläin
créature ressemblant à un crapaud ou à une grenouille [AUTOTRANSLATED]
Michigan J. Frog is a cartoon character whose first appearance was singing the song "Hello! Ma Baby".

table.name: mem
table.column: быть маленьким, быть небольшим, быть малым, быть мелким
A "match" is small, and is kept in a "match tin".

table.name: mem
table.column:
See the note under {mugh:v}.
Some word lists erroneously give another definition of {magh:v:nolink} with the meaning "indicate, reveal". This came from an old website called "Star Trek: Continuum", which had a "Klingon Linguistics Studies" section where someone (not Marc Okrand) took the official definitions and "expanded" them. This person apparently did not understand which meaning of the English word "betray" the Klingon word {magh:v:nolink} corresponded to.
René Magritte painted "La Trahison des images".

table.name: mem
table.column: This is a person who betrays someone. For a person who commits treason, see {'urwI':n}.
Речь идёт о человеке, который предаёт кого-то. Для лица, которое совершает измену смотрите {'urwI':n}.
René Magritte painted "La Trahison des images".

table.name: mem
table.column: This refers to a Klingon plant that most closely resembles grass.
In British English slang, to "grass on" someone means to betray them to a person in authority, such as police. (See {magh:v}.)

table.name: mem
table.column: A potboiler ({magh:n} + {pub:v}, using the fact that "pot" and "grass" have the same slang meaning) is a work of dubious literary merit.

table.name: mem
mem
table.column: This is a number-forming element, and not itself a number. The number 10 (ten) is {wa'maH:n:num}, literally "one ten", in Klingon.
Заметьте, что это числообразующий элемент, а не число само по себе. Число десять будет -{wa'maH:n:num}. Дословно переводится, как "один десять".

table.name: mem
table.column: This is a large bowl, used for serving {chatlh:n:1}, which diners pour into a {Duq:n} to eat.[1, p.99]
Это большая миска, используемая для подачи {chatlh:n:1}, который обедающий вливает в {Duq:n} чтобы есть.[1, стр.99]

table.name: mem
table.column:
This is an exclamation expressing satisfaction. For the verb (or adjective) meaning "to be good", see {QaQ:v}.
This word does not have the sense of "good" as used in a greeting, such as "good morning" or "good night". While there is an idiomatic expression in Klingon, {maj ram:sen:nolink}, which is used in a similar manner to "good night", it actually means something like "Good, (it is) night".[2]

Это выражение удовлетворения. Для глагола (или прилагательного) означающего "быть хорошим", смотрите {QaQ:v}.
Это слово не имеет смысл "добрый"(или "хороший") который используется в поздравлении или пожелании, такой как "доброе утро" или "доброй ночи". Есть идиоматическое выражение в Клингонском языке, {maj ram:sen:nolink}, которое используется на манер "доброй ночи". Дословно это значит что-то типа "Хорошо!!!Сейчас ночь".[2]

In {TNK:src}, "Good morning" is given as {maj po:excl:nolink}, "Good afternoon" as {maj pov:excl:nolink}, and "Good evening" as {maj choS:excl:nolink}. In {DS9 - The Sword of Kahless:src}, Jadzia Dax and Kor said {maj ram:excl:nolink} to each other as she headed for bed.
The writers who came up with this apparently looked up words for "good" and "night" and strung them together without regard for grammar or meaning.

table.name: mem
table.column: eräs kaalia tai salaattia muistuttava kasvi
This is the closest Klingon equivalent. It is closer to lettuce than to cabbage, but could be used for either Terran plant.[1]
{ma-:v:pref} and {-jaj:v:suff} make "may we", or in other words, "let us".

table.name: mem
table.column: The first element of this word appears to be {maj:excl}. The second element may be related to {Qap:v:1}.

table.name: mem
table.column: This refers to a piece of material used in construction.
Mahjong (麻將) is a Chinese game played with tiles.

table.name: mem
table.column: This refers to a person who lays tiles, as when constructing a floor.

▶ Paramount Pictures {malja' permey bIH:sen:nolink} Star Trek {pong'e' Deghmey'e' je.:sen:nolink}[2]

table.name: mem
table.column: This refers to the seed case of a plant. This would not be used for an escape pod or the like.[1]

table.column: soldat (en krigare i en grupp om flera)

The word {mangpu':n@@mang:n, -pu':n} is seldom-used, and carries the notion that there are individuals making up the group. {negh:n} focuses on the group as a unit. {QaS:n:1h} is similar to {negh:n:nolink}, but excludes officers.[2]

table.name: mem
table.column: This refers to all of the {negh:n} together.[2]

table.name: mem
table.column: This is not used as a title.[1, p.53]
Это не используется, как звание.[1, p.53]

table.name: mem
table.column: This is a place where medium/long range transport arrive and depart.[1]

table.name: mem
table.column:
{SkyBox S31:src} has the line {ghoS tlhIngan SuvwI' maq:sen:nolink}, where {maq:v:nolink} is used without {'e':n:pro}, but it is not known whether this is a typo or a feature of how {maq:v:nolink} is used.
This was used to translate "print" or "output" (i.e., display something to the user, such as the value of a variable) for Klingon Blockly.[2]

table.name: mem
table.column: This word is gender-neutral. If a distinction is required, add {loD:n} or {be':n}.
This seems to consist of "proclaim" ({maq:v}) and "see" ({legh:v}).

table.name: mem
table.column: buddy, pal, close male friend of a male
Kumpel, Freund (enger männlicher Freund eines Mannes)
دوست پسر، دوست نزدیک مرد دوست مرد [AUTOTRANSLATED]
polare, nära manlig vän till en man
дружок, дружбан, приятель, близкий друг мужского пола лица мужского пола
amigo, colega, amigo íntimo masculino de um homem
copain, copain, ami proche d'un homme [AUTOTRANSLATED]

This word is used by one male in addressing another male who is a close friend. Use of this word in other contexts may be considered insulting or offensive. The word may derive from {may' qoch:n@@may':n, qoch:n}. It is not uncommon for a Klingon father to address his son as {maqoch:n:nolink}, but not the other way around.

Слово используется одним лицом мужского пола, адресуемое другому лицу(того же пола), являющемуся близким другом. Использование этого слова в других контекстах может быть сочтено оскорбительным или обидным. Слово может происходить от {may' qoch:n@@may':n, qoch:n}. Не является редким для Клингонского отца, который адресует подобное слово сыну {maqoch:n:nolink}, но не наоборот.
"My coach". See also {qoch:n}. Note that {maqoch:sen@@ma-:v, qoch:v} may be read as a sentence.

table.name: mem
table.column: eräs mehiläistä tai ampiaista muistuttava eläin

This is the closest thing to a Terran bee or wasp. When necessary to specify a honey bee, it's simply {DayqIr maqSung:n@@DayqIr:n, maqSung:n}. A common way to specify a wasp is {maqSung qej:n@@maqSung:n, qej:v}.[1]
The queen is called the {maqSung SoS:n@@maqSung:n, SoS:n} or {maqSung SoS'a':n@@maqSung:n, SoS:n, -'a':n}.[1]

Another way to refer to the crescent moon is {maS'e' loQHa' So'lu'bogh:n}.[2]

In the original Klingon version of {yulyuS qaySar:n:name} (Julius Caesar), the titular character is warned to beware the {maS'e' So'bogh pagh:n:nolink}. It is unclear why this was changed to the "ides" of March in the translation.[1]

Мальц это пленник от Федерации, который живёт в подвале Марка Окранда, и который является источником знаний Федерации о Клингонском языке.

The literal meaning of this idiomatic expression is "to sing a different battle song". When uttered, it is frequently preceded by {DaH:adv} or {toH:excl}.
▶ {DaH may' bom pIm Dabom.:sen:nolink} "Well, that's another matter altogether."

table.column: When a warrior goes to a battle, he does not abandon his friends.
Wenn ein Krieger in die Schlacht zieht, lässt er seine Freunde nicht alleine.
هنگامی که یک جنگجو به یک نبرد می رود، دوستانش را ترک نمی کند. [AUTOTRANSLATED]
När en krigare går till en kamp, ​​överger han inte sina vänner. [AUTOTRANSLATED]
Когда воин идёт в битву, он не оставляет своих друзей
戰士去戰鬥時不會拋棄他的朋友。
Quando um guerreiro vai para uma batalha, ele não abandona seus amigos.
Kun soturi menee taisteluun, hän ei hylkää ystäviään.
Lorsqu’un guerrier part au combat, il n’abandonne pas ses amis. [AUTOTRANSLATED]

table.name: mem
table.column: This refers to a set of equipment (perhaps also including uniforms), not a formation of soldiers.[2]
A well-known announcer's test, which is a standard text given to someone wanting to be a radio or television announcer, has a line which says "seven thousand Macedonians in full battle array".

table.name: mem
table.column: This is a reference to Myron Floren, accordionist on "The Lawrence Welk Show".

table.name: mem
table.column: There is no instrument like a piano in traditional Klingon culture, but Klingons have seen them and use this term to refer to one. This is made up of {may'ron:n}, a Klingon instrument reminiscent of an accordian, and {raS:n} "table", as if an instrument of this type is a {may'ron:n:nolink} built into a table. Even though the term ignores the fact that a piano or harpsicord creates sound via vibrating strings, it's used for all of these keyboard instruments anyway. If clarification is needed, a piano or harpsicord could be a {SIrgh may'ron raS:n@@SIrgh:n, may'ron:n, raS:n}. To distinguish a piano from a harpsicord, one could use {SIrgh pangwI' may'ron raS:n@@SIrgh:n, pang:v, -wI':v, may'ron:n, raS:n} for harpsicord and {SIrgh moqwI' may'ron raS:n@@SIrgh:n, moq:v, -wI':v, may'ron:n, raS:n} for piano. (Occasionally, and in appropriate contexts, these could be shortened by leaving out the {may'ron:n}.) An organ (if it is necessary to distinguish it from these other instruments) would be a {SuS may'ron raS:n@@SuS:n, may'ron:n, raS:n}, even though that's a bit redundant.[1]

table.name: mem
table.column: inhysa, ge husrum, betjäna, utrusta, förse
MO accommodated the filmmakers by changing {qama':sen@@qa-:v, ma':v} to mean "prisoner" while {Star Trek III:src} was being filmed. See {qama'pu' jonta' neH.:sen}

table.name: mem
table.column: A death ritual that allows one who has lost honor to die well and go to Sto-Vo-Kor by being honorably killed by a House-mate or someone equally close.

Ein Todesritual, das es jemandem, der die Ehre verloren hat, ermöglicht, gut zu sterben und nach Sto-Vo-Kor zu gehen, indem er von einem Mitbewohner oder einer ähnlich nahen Person ehrenvoll getötet wird.

Смертельный ритуал, который позволяет тому, кто потерял честь, умереть достойно и почить в Стовокорре, будучи убитым. Ритуал проводит член дома, в котором состоит Клингон, или кто-то достаточно близкий.

This is written as {ma' to'vor:n:nolink} in the glossary to {Diplomatic Implausibility:src}, but the space appears to be a typo, as the word appears as {ma'to'vor:n:nolink} in the glossary to {A Good Day to Die:src}.
[1] {DS9 - Sons of Mogh:src}, [2] {Diplomatic Implausibility:src}, [3] {A Good Day to Die:src}

table.name: mem
table.column: ett slags ceremoniell kniv, mevak (används i Mauk-To'Vor-ritualen)
The "M'veQ" is a ceremonial knife used in the ritual of "Mauk To'Vor" ({ma'to'vor:n}).
М'Век это церемониальный нож, используемый для ритуала Мактовор ({ma'to'vor:n}).
This word's spelling was confirmed by MO. However, in the glossary to the non-canon {A Good Day to Die:src}, DeCandido writes this as {mevaq:n:nolink} "mevak dagger".
[1] {DS9 - Sons of Mogh:src}, [2] {KLI mailing list 1999.02.12:src}, [3] {KLI mailing list 2010.12.29:src}, [4] {paq'batlh 2ed p.180-181:src}

table.column:
This is the reverse of {ghem:n}.
The movie "When Harry Met Sally" has an infamous lunch scene. Sally is played by Meg Ryan.

table.name: mem
table.column: end (of stick, rope, etc.), other end from {'er'In:n}
Ende (von Stab, Schnur, usw.), das gegenüberliegende Ende heißt {'er'In:n}
پایان (از چوب، طناب، و غیره)، پایان دیگری از {'er'In:n} [AUTOTRANSLATED]
конец (палки, веревки и т. д.), другой конец от {'er'In:n} [AUTOTRANSLATED]
結束（棍棒、繩索等）、另一端來自{'er'In:n} [AUTOTRANSLATED]

extrémité (du bâton, de la corde, etc.), autre extrémité de {'er'In:n} [AUTOTRANSLATED]

This can refer to either end of the rope, stick or whatever, but once you arbitrarily choose an end to call {megh'an:n:nolink}, the other end is called {'er'In:n:nolink}. Before you make this initial reference, either end can be called either {'er'In:n:nolink} or {megh'an:n:nolink}.
This is a private joke referring to a specific person.

table.name: mem
table.column: The word for the kind of bridge that goes over a river, or connects two locations, is {QI:n}.
Для слова мост(сооружение через реку), смотрите {QI:n}.

table.name: mem
table.column:
There is no single word for "art" or "artwork", in the sense of individual pieces of visual art (painting, sculpture, etc.).
{meHghem:n:nolink} is a bigger, more comprehensive term covering "the arts" or "art" as opposed to "science". It includes music, theater, dance, etc., as well as visual art. It's "culture" in this sense.
The fact that there is no single word for "art" or "artwork" is stated on {KGT p.79:src}.

table.name: mem
table.column: ▶ {tera' DIS cha' pagh wa' wej meHghem Qat Sub boq cherlu'.:sen:nolink} "In 2013, Popular Culture Hero Coalition was established."
[1] {Pop Culture Hero Coalition announcement:src} ({KLI mailing list 2016.11.30:src})

table.name: mem
table.column: lämna, avvika, ge sig av, avlägsna sig

While {mej:v:nolink} refers simply to leaving one's current location, {tlheD:v} generally implies setting out on a journey, with a goal or destination in mind. In both cases, the object is the place you're leaving or departing from.[3]
The suffix {-vo':n:suff} (with the no-object prefix) is used when the place that one is leaving is a starting point. Without the suffix (and with the prefix indicating an object), it simply means that one is no longer at a place they've been. It's also possible to have both a starting point marked with {-vo'} and a place as the object, in which case one is leaving the place from that starting point.[5]
If a Klingon had to say "goodbye", they might say {DaH jImej:sen@@DaH:adv, jI-:v, mej:v}, literally "I'm leaving now".[2] Of course, in most situations a Klingon would just leave, without superfluous niceties such as declaring his or her intention to do so.
This would not normally be used of an inanimate object, for which see {ngab:v} (or {loj:v} if something goes away gradually).[4]
To express leaving a person or object (rather than a location), consider {lon:v}.

The {TNK:src} software forces all languages to follow a template, which includes expressions such as "hello", "goodbye", and colour words which don't have a natural translation in Klingon.
There are situations in which a Klingon might actually say {DaH jImej:sen:nolink}. See the examples under {ghIm:v} and {qIvon belmoH:sen}.
The example sentences from the mailing list came out of a discussion about revisions to the {paq'batlh:src}.

▶ {bIghHa' DamejDI' pagh QaS yInob.:sen} ▶ {chalqachlIjvo' bImej:sen:nolink} (you leave, with your tower as a starting point)[5] ▶ {chalqachlIj Damej:sen:nolink} (you leave your tower, where you had previously been)[5] ▶ {lojmItmeyvo' ghe'tor Damejta':sen:nolink} (you left Gre'thor from the gates)[5]

table.name: mem
table.column: The idiom "apron strings" refers to one's ties to one's parents, which one leaves ({mej:v}) when one is married ({nay:v}).

table.name: mem
table.column: This was shortened over time from {mejmeH 'aD:n@@mej:v, -meH:v, 'aD:n}.

table.name: mem
table.column: A character in a famous Klingon opera.

table.name: mem
table.column: This refers more generally to anything on its way to becoming something else. For example, it could be used for a lump of clay being transformed into a pot (but is not yet a pot). As slang, it could refer to a student or athlete or warrior in training, but not yet up to speed, as it were.[1]
Backwards of "golem", which is a Hebrew word meaning "pupa", but also referring to a mythological creature created from clay.

table.name: mem
table.column: reason, motive, logical thinking, topic, subject, theme
دلیل، انگیزه، تفکر منطقی، موضوع، موضوع، موضوع [AUTOTRANSLATED]
причина, мотив, логичное мышление, тема, субъект, предмет обсуждения
理性、動機、邏輯思維、主題、主題、主題 [AUTOTRANSLATED]
razão, motivo, pensamento lógico, tema, assunto, tópico
raison, motif, pensée logique, sujet, sujet, thème [AUTOTRANSLATED]
This can be used to refer to the topic, subject, or theme of a conversation, story, etc. (That is, it describes the "reason" or "motive" for the conversation or story.)
Это может быть использовано, чтобы упомянуть о теме разговора, обсуждения, разговора и т.д.

This is defined as "reason" in {TKD:src} and as "motive" in the word lists in {KGT:src}. It is also glossed as "logical thinking" (in the sense of "motive") in the body of {KGT:src} on p.154. At {qep'a' 25 (2018):src}, its definition was expanded to include "topic, subject, theme".
This was also used for the "logic" menu (instructions about program flow control) in Klingon Blockly.[3]

table.name: mem
table.column: This is defined only as "reason" in {TKD:src}. The definition was later expanded.[2]

table.name: mem
table.column: This is the portion of a trial or appeal where the evidence is heard.
Это часть разбирательства или аппеляции, когда заслушано доказательство

table.name: mem
table.column:
This word only appears as a part of {yu'egh meqHoD 'och:n:nolink} "Waveform Bypass Conduit". It was confirmed to have come from Maltz at {qep'a' 30 (2023):src}.[2]
You say "bye" to someone who is doing the action of {DoH:v}, and when you ask a waiter to {qem:v} something, they "pass" it to you.

table.column: mek'leth (type of weapon; smaller, one-handed version of bat'leth)

{meqleH:n:nolink} также называется {meqleH matlh:n:nolink}, чтобы отличить от {betleH:n}, который звучит похоже.
This is defined as "mek'leth (type of weapon)" in the word lists.

table.name: mem
table.column: In some dialects in this region, {letlh:n:2} refers only to the stairway connected to a ship, and {ngep'oS:n} refers to every other kind of stairway.
В некоторых диалектах в данном регионе, {letlh:n:2} относится только к лестнице, соединённой с кораблём, а {ngep'oS:n} от носится ко всем остальным видам лестниц.
This word appears only in the body of {KGT:src} on p.29 and not in the glossary. It appears as {meqro'vaq:n:nolink} and not as {meqro'vaq Sep:n:nolink}, but it is described as a region (see {Sep:n}).

In general usage, the meaning of this verb is that the subject is on fire. {meQmoH:v@@meQ:v:1, -moH:v} would be used if the subject sets the object on fire.[4]
Due to the influence of {mIQ:v}, this verb is used differently in the context of food preparation. There, the subject of this verb burns the object ({meQ:v:2}). As well, it can be used adjectivally for something that is burnt ({meQ:v:3}).[4]

"Polttaa" on {meQmoH:v@@meQ:v:1, -moH:v} [4].
Ruoanlaiton yhteydessä verbiä käytetään voi käyttää transitiivisessa merkityksessä "polttaa, kypsentää" (ks. {meQ:v:2}) tai adjektiivina "olla poltettu, kypsennetty" (ks. {meQ:v:3}) johtuen verbin {mIQ:v} vaikutuksesta [4].

This was originally defined just as "burn" in {TKD:src}. Its definition was clarified to "burn, be on fire", and its special usage in food preparation contexts explained, in a message to the mailing list.[4]

table.name: mem
table.column: This is "the banner of unity and revolution" used by {qeylIS'e' lIjlaHbe'bogh vay':n:name} to rally his troops.
Это "флаг единства и революции" использовался {qeylIS'e' lIjlaHbe'bogh vay':n:name} чтобы сплотить его войска.

table.name: mem
table.column: The command {yImev:sen@@yI-:v, mev:v} means to stop doing something. It would not be used for stopping a device (such as an engine).[2]

The only object this verb has taken in canon is {'e':n:pro}, and in every case the subject of {mev:v:nolink} has been identical to the subject of the sentence-as-object. It seems that the subject is what stops or ceases, even when there is an object. It is notable that {mevmoH:v@@mev:v, -moH:v} appears on {KGT p.154:src} as "cause [someone] to stop".

table.name: mem
table.column: cope (with), deal well (with), handle (a difficulty or challenge)
(mit etwas) zurechtkommen, gut (mit etwas) zurechtkommen, (mit einer Schwierigkeit oder Herausforderung) umgehen
کنار آمدن (با)، به خوبی کنار آمدن (با)، رسیدگی به (یک مشکل یا چالش) [AUTOTRANSLATED]

faire face (à), bien gérer (avec), gérer (une difficulté ou un défi) [AUTOTRANSLATED]

When used with an object, it could be a person, a thing, an activity, or an event. The object can also be {'e':n:pro}. This verb is used when the subject is considered to be mentally or emotionally able to deal with an object felt to be undesirable, difficult, challenging, daunting, stressful, or unpleasant.[1]
Though appropriate in some circumstances and grammatically fine, when this verb is negated, Klingons are unlikely to use it with a first-person subject.[1]
▶ {qagh Qop DaSop 'e' Damew'laH'a'?:sen@@qagh:n, Qop:v:2, Da-:v, Sop:v, 'e':n, Da-:v, mew':v, -laH:v, -'a':v} "Can you cope with eating dead gagh?"

▶ {mumey waqmeywIj:sen@@mu-:v, mey:v, waq:n, -mey:n, -wIj:n} "my shoes fit" (literally, "my shoes fit me") ▶ {torgh lumey waqmey:sen@@torgh:n:name, lu-:v, mey:v, waq:n, -mey:n} "the shoes fit Torg" ▶ {waqmeywIj vImey:sen@@waq:n, -mey:n, -wIj:n, vI-:v, mey:v} "I fit my shoes"

▶ {mumey waqmeywIj:sen@@mu-:v, mey:v, waq:n, -mey:n, -wIj:n} "meine Schuhe passen" (wörtlich: "meine Schuhe passen mir") ▶ {torgh lumey waqmey:sen@@torgh:n:name, lu-:v, mey:v, waq:n, -mey:n} "die Schuhe passen Torg" ▶ {waqmeywIj vImey:sen@@waq:n, -mey:n, -wIj:n, vI-:v, mey:v} "ich passe in meine Schuhe"

This is technically a {letbaQ HoS:n@@letbaQ:n, HoS:v}.
This word can also refer to the "diamond" suit in a deck of playing cards (see {Degh:n:1}).[2]

table.column: A n-sided polygon is an {n reD mey':n:nolink} for n > 3. For example: {loS reD mey':n}, {vagh reD mey':n}.

table.column: The child of a {me':n:nolink} is a {tey':n:1}.
This is a reference to Aunt "Em" from The Wizard of Oz.

table.column: This is the closest thing to a grasshopper, and could also be used for a locust or cricket.

table.column: быть злым, быть порочным, быть зловещим

table.name: mem
table.column: This word (or a homophone) also appears as a component of {SuS mIjDang:n} and {rewve' mIjDang:n}.
It isn't known whether this word still takes the body part suffix when used to refer to a device such as {SuS mIjDang:n:nolink}.

table.name: mem
table.column: vara fordom ärad, vara tidigare hedrad

Loss of honor is implied by this verb, which is used as an adjective to describe one who has fallen from grace. It is not applicable to someone who would be described as {'utlh:n}, a word which implies a voluntary, honorable retirement.
This is a reference to Richard "Mil"house Nixon.

table.name: mem
table.column: This word can be used for any sort of depiction, including drawings, photographs, cartoons, icons on 21st-century computers, and so on.
This is a combination of the Latin word for "thousand" with the Greek word for "word".

table.name: mem
table.column: This expression is used to refer specifically to a single-panel cartoon (like most political cartoons), regardless of whether the shape of the panel is actually a square (see {meyrI':n}) or not. In comparison, the expression {mIllogh mIr:n} is used for comic strips regardless of the number of panels, including for single-panel cartoons.[1]

table.name: mem
table.column: This refers to a non-animated cartoon or comic strip. Despite its literal meaning (see {mIr:n:1}), this is used whether there are a number of panels (as in a comic book or most newspaper comics), or just a single panel (like most political cartoons). To refer to a single-panel cartoon specifically, one usually uses {mIllogh meyrI':n}.[1]

table.name: mem
table.column: Since {ngutlh:n} refers specifically to symbols used to represent language, this would not be misunderstood as pictogram. (A hierography corresponds to a linguistic element, whereas a pictogram corresponds to a concept or idea.)[1]

table.name: mem
table.column:
This refers to animation only, and not to printed cartoons in the newspaper.[1] Even though {qol:n:1h} refers to a multitude of things, they are being treated as a collection, so one would say {qolmey:n@@qol:n:1h, -mey:n} for multiple cartoons.[2]
To refer to a non-animated cartoon, see {mIllogh mIr:n} and {mIllogh meyrI':n}.

At the Q & A session at {Saarbrücken qepHom'a' 2021:src}, it was explained that {qol:n:1h,nolink} is a noun, but its meaning was not revealed then. The meaning was subsequently revealed in the booklet, which was published later.[2]

table.name: mem
table.column: Note that this word is singular, unlike the English word "sunglasses".

table.name: mem
table.column: This is the most common way to refer to a person who performs magic. For a true wizard or sorcerer, see {'IDnar pIn'a':n}.

table.name: mem
table.column: While Klingons have no native word for a drop of tear, they would understand this term to refer to a drop of liquid coming from the eye.

table.name: mem
table.column: This refers to the possession of wealth, rather than the ability to produce wealth. For example, land is not said to be "rich" (in minerals, etc.) in this sense.[2]
This was clarified at the Q & A session at {qep'a' 28 (2021):src}.

table.name: mem
table.column: ▶ {DojneS mIplIj.:sen@@Doj:v, -neS:v, mIp:n, -lIj:n} "Your wealth is impressive, your honor."[2]

table.name: mem
table.column: This is a reference to McDonald's, which is known as "Mickey D's".

table.name: mem
table.column: A Klingon forehead looks like it's deep-fried.

table.name: mem
table.column: This can also be used metaphorically or symbolically (see {mIr:n:2}). As well, if things are clear, it can be used as a slang term to mean {wIyqap:n} or {lanSoy:n} (though probably not {wev:n}).

table.name: mem
table.column: "Meerschaum", also known as sepiolite, is a material from which some smoking pipes are made.

Шекспировская пьеса {paghmo' tIn mIS:sen:nolink}, дословно "Велико смущение из ничего", было переведено, как "Много шума из ничего" {tlhIngan Hol yejHaD:n}.

"Mish" mash.
This was clarified to mean "mental confusion" at {qep'a' 24 (2017):src}.

The English spelling of this name was never given in {KCD:src}. The spelling is therefore uncertain.

This expression literally means "to display a glove on one's helmet", and is used to convey the idea that a matter has been postponed or rescheduled. The phrase takes a number of forms, as appropriate to the parties to the commitment. For example, {mIvwIjDaq poghlIj vIcha':sen:nolink} "I display your glove on my helmet" implies that the postponed matter is between the speaker and the addressee.
This idiom has its origin in {HenrI' vagh:n:name}, a play by {wIlyam SeQpIr:n:name}.

table.column:
This is a scar which is the result of a wound (regardless of how the wound occurred).[1] A scar that results from surgery is a {mIvwa':n:nolink} and not a {roptoj:n:nolink}.[3]
A tally or score is kept by counting {mIvwa'mey:n@@mIvwa':n, -mey:n}. This is also used for "census" or "headcount".[2]

The appropriate word for a surgery scar was explained during the Q & A session at {Saarbrücken qepHom'a' 2021:src}.[3]

This was defined as "procedure, process" in {TKD:src}, as "step, stage (in a process)" in {KGT:src}, and expanded to include "recipe, formula (prodecure, process)" at {qep'a' 26 (2019):src}.
This was used to refer to a concept in computer programming, namely, a compartmentalized piece of computer code which has inputs and outputs and is used over and over, in Klingon Blockly.[3]

table.name: mem
table.column: This refers to the process that happens at a court of law.

table.name: mem
table.column:
Basic number-forming elements include {maH:n:2,num}, {vatlh:n:num}, {SaD:n:num} ({SanID:n:num}), {netlh:n:num}, {bIp:n:num}, {'uy':n:num}, {Saghan:n:num}.
A number-forming element must be combined with a number from one to nine, so that 10,000 (ten thousand), for example, is {wa'netlh:n:num,nolink} (and not just {netlh:n:num,nolink}). Combining multiple number-forming elements is possible, so that 10,000,000 (ten million), for example, is {wa'maH'uy':n:num,nolink}.
When a number is used for numbering (labeling), as opposed to counting, it follows the noun. Ordinal numbers are formed with {-DIch:n:num,suff}. Repetitions are formed with {-logh:n:num,suff}.
▶ {ghogh HablI' mI' yIper:sen:nolink} "What is the telephone number?"[2]

table.name: mem
table.column: умри, игра в кости с числами [AUTOTRANSLATED]

In {Klingon Monopoly:src}, {mI' naghmey:n:nolink} refers to the playing dice. The verb {ronmoH:v@@ron:v:1, -moH:v} is used for the action of throwing or rolling the dice.
The verb {'al:v:2} is used for random numbers ({mI' 'al:n}).

table.name: mem
table.column: The so-called "prefix trick" may be used with some verbs: if a verb has a third-person direct object and a first- or second-person indirect object, the pronomial prefix which normally indicates a first- or second-person object may be used. An example of this is {tIqwIj Sa'angnIS.:sen}[2] The "prefix trick" may also work with a third-person indirect object in some situations.[3]

table.name: mem
table.column: This refers to a quadrilateral with no parallel sides. If it has parallel sides, it is called a {qarpal:n}.
Dies bezieht sich auf ein Viereck ohne parallele Seiten. Wenn zwei Seiten parallel sind, nennt man es {qarpal:n}.
Epäkäs on nelikulmio, jonka kaikki sivut ovat erisuuntaisia. Kuviota, jolla on yhdensuuntaisia sivuja, sanotaan puolisuunnikkaaksi ({qarpal:n}).

The word "trapezium" also refers to a bone ({Hom:n:1}) in the wrist ({yeb:n:1}).
In British English, this word refers to what would be called a general irregular quadrilateral (whereas the word "trapezium" refers to what in American English would be called a "trapezoid").

table.name: mem
table.column: This can also be written as {morwI' ghew:n@@morwI':n, ghew:n}. It is the closest Klingon equivalent to an ant, based on appearance. The Klingon version is noted for its dexterity or agility, hence the name (see {mor:v}), and not for its strength. But Klingons use this term for the Terran ant anyway.[1]

The Proto-Indo-European word for ant is reconstructed as "*morwi-".
The request was for "ant(s), formicidae" with the plural in brackets, and the answer was given as two possibilities, {morwI', morwI' ghew:sen:nolink}.

table.name: mem
table.column:
This is a planet which has become part of the Klingon Empire. On this planet, a dialect of Klingon has all but replaced any languages originally spoken.[2, p.17]
In the Morskan dialect, {tlh:sen:nolink} at the end of a syllable is pronounced like "ts" (like in "cats"), while at the beginning it is pronounced like {ghl:sen:nolink}. {H:sen:nolink} at the beginning of syllables is pronounced like "h" (like in "hat"), while it is not pronounced at all at the ends of syllables. {Q:sen:nolink} at the beginning of syllables is pronounced the same as a standard {H:sen:nolink}.[2, p.22]
The Morskan dialect does not put the suffix {-'e':n:suff} on the subject noun in a "to be" sentence. When it is present, it serves its usual focusing function.[2, p.24]
The Morskan dialect is featured in {Star Trek VI:src}, in a scene involving border guards on the way to {rura' pente':n}.

table.column: ser legal (de acordo com a lei)

table.name: mem
table.column:
In a general context, this word means to "present", as in "present a gift" to someone.[2]
This verb is also used in music ({much:v:2}) and martial arts ({much:v:3}).

Em um contexto geral, esta palavra significa "presentear", como em "presentear um presente" a alguém.[2]
Este verbo também é usado em música ({much:v:2}) e artes marciais ({much:v:3}).

table.name: mem
table.column: strike a pose or stance (martial arts)
اعتصاب یک موضع یا موضع (هنرهای رزمی) [AUTOTRANSLATED]
fazer uma pose ou postura (artes marciais)
prendre une pose ou une position (arts martiaux) [AUTOTRANSLATED]

This is the verb {much:v:1} applied to martial arts, where it means to strike a pose or a stance (see {lol:v:1}). The object is the name of the pose or stance, which usually ends in {tonSaw':n}. If the context is clear, {tonSaw':n:nolink} can be left out.
▶ {mIl'oD tonSaw' yImuch:sen@@mIl'oD:n, tonSaw':n, yI-:v, much:v:3} "strike the sabre bear pose!" ▶ {mIl'oD yImuch:sen@@mIl'oD:n, yI-:v, much:v:3} "strike the sabre bear (pose)!"

The term {DawI' yaH:n@@DawI':n, yaH:n} was used for "stage" in Hamlet.

table.name: mem
table.column: The word for weather, meaning the state of the atmosphere, is the same word as for the atmosphere itself (see {muD:n:2}).[2]
Слово для погоды, означающее состояние атмосферы, это тоже самое слово, как и для атмосферы (смотрите {muD:n:2}).[2]
It was confirmed by MO at {Saarbrücken qepHom'a' 2022:src} that this is a reference to the 1961 film "The Sky Above, The Mud Below".

table.name: mem
table.column: The word for weather, meaning the state of the atmosphere, is the same word as for the atmosphere itself (see {muD:n:1}). When inquiring about weather conditions at a specific time and/or place, the expression {muD Dotlh:n} is used.[2]

table.name: mem
table.column: The Klingon word for "weather" in the sense of the state of the atmosphere is just {muD:n:2}, the same word as for the atmosphere itself ({muD:n:1}). The expression {muD Dotlh:n:nolink} is used when inquiring about weather conditions at a specific time and/or place.[2]

A {mutlhwI':n:nolink} is a person who puts things together.
A person who repairs things is a {tI'wI':n}. Most {mutlhwI'pu':n:nolink} are also {tI'wI'pu':n:nolink}.
When applied to {tlhIm:n}, {mutlh:v:nolink} means to assemble the carpet. The verb for laying a carpet is {vel:v}.

The original definition given on the {KLI mailing list:src} was "construct, assemble, put together". This word was also defined as "manufacture, construct, put together" in the {Saarbrücken qepHom'a' 2016:src} booklet.
▶ {ngogh mutlhwI':n} "bricklayer" ▶ {majyang mutlhwI':n} "tiler" ▶ {beb mutlhwI':n} "roofer" ▶ {'och mutlhwI':n} "plumber" ▶ {'ul pat mutlhwI':n} "electrician"
